title: Defying the resource curse: explaining successful state-owned enterprises in rentier states
abstract: The article explains how several Gulf rentier monarchies have managed to create highly profitable and well-managed state-owned enterprises (soes), confounding expectations of both general soe inefficiency and the particularly poor quality of rentier public sectors. It argues that a combination of two factors explains the outcome: the absence of a populist-mobilizational history and substantive regime autonomy in economic policy-making. The author concludes that it is necessary to rethink the commonly accepted generalizations both about rentier states and, arguably, about public sectors in the developing world
